Yevgeny Prigozhin, the head of Wagner, may have had support from Russia's military in his plans to rebel against the country's leadership. U.S. officials are trying to determine if General Sergei Surovikin, the former top Russian commander in Ukraine, was involved in the plans. If so, it would be the latest sign of infighting in the Russian military and could signal a wider fracture between supporters of Prigozhin and President Vladimir V. Putin. The Kremlin has denied the claims and insists that Russia is unified around Putin. U.S. officials are also looking into the possibility that other Russian generals may have supported Prigozhin's attempt to change the leadership of the Defense Ministry. If evidence of General Surovikin's involvement is found, Putin will have to decide how to respond. American officials have an interest in pushing out information that undermines the standing of General Surovikin, as they view him as more competent and more likely to challenge Putin.
